study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess current metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) practice patterns among pediatric surgeons in the United States.
results_summary: Only 4.2% of surveyed surgeons performed MBS in the past year, with most believing high surgical volume improves outcomes. Adolescent MBS programs commonly included multidisciplinary teams, but few surgeons had additional MBS training.
population_specificity: Pediatric surgeons in the United States, specifically those performing metabolic and bariatric surgery on adolescents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of physical training on cortisol and testosterone responses in women after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Physical training post-bariatric surgery led to beneficial hormonal and physical adaptations, including reduced cortisol response and lower heart rate during exercise, while blood lactate increases disappeared in both groups.
population_specificity: Post-bariatric surgery women (11 in the PA group, 9 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 3-month physical training program (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review endoscopic management techniques for weight recurrence following bariatric surgery, focusing on Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The study highlights that endoscopic bariatric therapy is a minimally invasive option for managing weight recurrence, with varying short- and mid-term weight loss outcomes and known adverse events. It emphasizes a multidisciplinary approach to address anatomical, nutritional, psychological, and social factors contributing to weight recurrence.
population_specificity: Patients with weight recurrence following bariatric surgery (specifically RYGB and SG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of endoscopic vacuum therapy (EVT) for treating post-surgical leaks and fistulas following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: EVT showed an 87.2% clinical success rate, with 6% moderate adverse events and 12.5% system dislodgements, requiring frequent system exchanges and prolonged hospitalization. The study suggests EVT is safe and effective but cautions interpretation due to limited data.
population_specificity: Patients with post-bariatric surgery leaks and fistulas.
study_duration: Average dwell time of 25.67 days, total hospitalization of 44.43 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop recommendations for preventing and treating osteoporosis secondary to bariatric surgery, focusing on fracture risk assessment and management.
results_summary: The study recommends measures like normalizing calcium and protein intake, maintaining vitamin D levels, and assessing fracture risk, particularly for high-risk groups such as postmenopausal women and men over 50. Anti-osteoporosis treatment (e.g., zoledronic acid) is advised for specific high-risk cases.
population_specificity: Patients with an indication for or who have undergone bariatric surgery, especially postmenopausal women and men ≥50 years old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a home telehealth core stabilization exercise program on core stability, postural control, and aerobic capacity in patients after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that an 8-week home-based telehealth core stabilization program significantly improved core endurance, postural stability, and aerobic capacity in post-bariatric surgery patients, while the control group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the health-related quality of life (HRQOL) benefits of bariatric surgery persist at least nine years post-surgery.
results_summary: The review found that bariatric surgery provides persistent HRQOL benefits, particularly in physical components, though psychological factors may reduce effectiveness for some patients. Inconsistent study methodologies limited the strength of the evidence.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery with at least a 9-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the association between physical activity, weight regain, metabolic risk factors, and quality of life in patients who underwent bariatric surgery, as well as preliminarily assess links between physical activity, weight regain, sleep quality, and sedentary behavior.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery induced significant weight loss in the first year post-surgery, but lower physical activity levels were associated with weight regain. Quality of life and sleep quality were inversely related to weight regain, as was sedentary behavior.
population_specificity: 84 individuals who had undergone bariatric gastric bypass surgery at least five years prior to the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and sleeve gastrectomy (SG) on dynamic measures of β-cell function (BCF) in obese adults.
results_summary: Most studies indicated an increase in BCF and disposition index after both RYGB and SG, particularly with oral stimulation, with more pronounced effects in diabetic individuals. Limited evidence suggested greater effects after RYGB versus SG, but heterogeneity in testing protocols prevented meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Obese adults (total n=1856), including diabetic and nondiabetic individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of vitamin D on adipose tissue biology, including anti-inflammatory effects, adipocyte differentiation, and energy metabolism, in the context of human obesity and bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D has consistent anti-inflammatory effects on adipose tissue, but its impact on adipocyte differentiation, adipogenesis, and energy metabolism remains inconclusive. Vitamin D supplementation showed minimal or no improvement in vitamin D status post-bariatric surgery, and benefits for visceral adipose tissue reduction were only seen in a few studies.
population_specificity: Human obesity and bariatric surgery patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on patient-reported outcomes (PROs), such as health-related quality of life (HRQOL), in comparison to cardiometabolic outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery can improve PROs, including HRQOL, with weight loss positively influencing quality of life. Patient satisfaction was also noted to be affected by glycemic control, with hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia negatively impacting satisfaction.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and/or obesity (implied by focus on weight loss and glycemic control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery on polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) in terms of clinical, hormonal, and comorbidity outcomes in obese women.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly improved hirsutism (74.6% resolution at 6 months), restored normal menstrual cycles (93% at 6 months), and resolved comorbidities like T2DM, HTN, DLP, and OSA (79.7%-98.5% resolution) in obese women with PCOS.
population_specificity: 1013 PCOS patients with morbid obesity from a single high-volume center.
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 6 months to 5 years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of bariatric surgery on bone health, including bone mineral density, skeletal strength, and fracture risk.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery leads to accelerated bone loss, particularly at the hip, with persistent increases in bone resorption markers and structural deterioration (e.g., lower cortical density, higher porosity) for up to 5 years post-surgery, increasing fracture risk. These effects appear chronic and are influenced by malabsorption, mechanical unloading, and adipose-bone-muscle crosstalk.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (malabsorptive, mixed, or restrictive procedures).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the safety and efficacy of combining bariatric surgery (Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy) with goal-directed medical therapy to improve long-term glycaemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and obesity.
results_summary: The study is designed to compare the proportion of patients achieving HbA1c<6.5% at 1 year and a composite endpoint (HbA1c<6.5%, BP<130/80 mm Hg, LDL<2.6 mmol/L) at 5 years between bariatric surgery with standard care versus intensive medical therapy. Results are pending as this is a prospective trial.
population_specificity: 150 patients with obesity and T2DM recruited from tertiary care obesity centres.

study_goal: The abstract does not address bariatric surgery; it focuses on pediatric NAFLD, its genetic and environmental risk factors, and potential treatments.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss bariatric surgery or its effects.
population_specificity: Children with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of intuitive eating alone or combined with nutritional guidelines on eating behaviors, weight, and BMI in individuals with obesity, particularly candidates for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that intuitive eating, whether alone or combined with nutritional guidelines, did not significantly alter eating behaviors, weight, or BMI in individuals with obesity compared to the control group. No significant differences were observed in binge eating, cognitive restriction, emotional eating, or uncontrolled eating.
population_specificity: 58 individuals (84.5% female, 84.5% candidates for bariatric surgery) with a mean age of 40.5 years and mean BMI of 48.3 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the cost-effectiveness of metabolic surgery for treating comorbid type 2 diabetes (T2D) and obesity.
results_summary: Metabolic surgery was found to be cost-effective or cost-saving, with results robust to sensitivity analyses, though limitations included limited long-term follow-up data and uncertainty about T2D remission utility.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) or a subpopulation with T2D across 17 jurisdictions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two different very low-calorie diets (VLCDs) on weight reduction and metabolic parameters in patients awaiting bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Both VLCDs led to significant weight reduction (mean 5.24 kg) and improvements in excess weight loss, liver volume, and metabolic parameters, with no significant differences between the two diets. The study concluded that VLCDs are effective regardless of macronutrient composition.
population_specificity: Ninety patients awaiting obesity surgery, with 69 ultimately analyzed (33 on diet 1, 36 on diet 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a rapid weight reduction (RWR) therapy using liraglutide, leucine-rich amino acid infusion, and a hypocaloric diet as a pre-operative bridging intervention for patients with severe obesity (BMI ≥60 kg/m²) to achieve technical operability for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that RWR therapy led to rapid weight loss, achieving operability in all patients within approximately 2-4 weeks, with a mean weight loss of 27.5 kg compared to 20.9 kg in the control group (P = 0.0629). The therapy was deemed effective for acutely life-threatening severe obesity cases.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity (BMI ≥60 kg/m²) requiring urgent fast-track bridging for bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Mean RWR bridging duration was 20.7 ± 6.9 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term effects of resistance training and protein supplementation after bariatric surgery and analyze associations between habitual physical activity and weight regain at 5 years.
results_summary: The study found that early postoperative resistance training did not improve muscle strength after 5 years, but higher levels of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity were associated with lower weight regain. Weight loss was maintained at 32.8 kg on average, with a mean regain of 5.4 kg compared to the 12-month assessment.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery (initial n=76, follow-up n=54).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics of direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) after bariatric surgery and apply findings to clinical cases.
results_summary: The study found a substantial risk of DOAC malabsorption after bariatric surgery, with incidence rates for arterial thromboembolism, venous thromboembolism, and major bleeding being low but present. The pooled proportion of peak DOAC levels within the expected range was only 58%, indicating potential efficacy concerns.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery and were prescribed DOACs (n = 3229).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the amount of weight loss required to reduce intracranial pressure in women with idiopathic intracranial hypertension and to compare the effects of different bariatric surgical approaches.
results_summary: Weight loss was significantly associated with reduced intracranial pressure, with 24% weight loss linked to disease remission. Bariatric surgery achieved greater weight loss and intracranial pressure reduction compared to dietary intervention.
population_specificity: Adult women with active idiopathic intracranial hypertension and a body mass index ≥35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the level of discrimination experienced by patients with obesity in Poland and Germany, including differences based on treatment methods (bariatric surgery, endoscopic methods, or conservative treatment).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in obesity discrimination levels between German and Polish patients. However, patients who underwent bariatric surgery or endoscopic methods reported higher discrimination related to employment compared to those on conservative treatment. Discrimination levels were also associated with sex, age, obesity degree, and treatment-related weight loss.
population_specificity: 564 adult patients with morbid obesity treated at healthcare facilities in Germany (210) and Poland (354).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of bariatric surgery as a treatment option for obese youth patients with type 1 diabetes, alongside other interventions like insulinotherapy and new diabetes drugs.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that bariatric surgery has been reported as a treatment for obese diabetic patients, but it does not provide specific outcomes or efficacy data. The focus is on the broader challenges of obesity in type 1 diabetes and the potential use of various treatments.
population_specificity: Youth patients with type 1 diabetes who are overweight or obese, particularly adolescents, with a higher prevalence in girls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery (specifically SG and RYGB) influences return to work among unemployed patients.
results_summary: One year after surgery, 39.39% of SG patients and 33.85% of RYGB patients returned to work, but the difference between procedures was not statistically significant. The study concluded that bariatric surgery has a positive effect on employment but found no procedure-specific influences.
population_specificity: Unemployed patients in Germany who underwent primary SG or RYGB between 2015 and 2020 (n=782).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether participation in postoperative educational programs lasting 2-3 years after RYGB influences long-term weight loss, weight regain, physical activity, and compliance to multivitamin supplements.
results_summary: Frequent attendees of educational programs had significantly better total weight loss (23.2% vs. 19.5%) and excess weight loss (55.7% vs. 46.0%) compared to infrequent attendees, with a trend toward less weight regain. No differences were found in multivitamin compliance or physical activity between groups.
population_specificity: Individuals who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) for severe obesity.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (educational program participation, not a dosage-based intervention).
study_duration: 10-15 years post-surgery (educational programs lasted 2-3 years postoperatively).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the incidence, symptoms, diagnosis, and management of splenic complications following bariatric/metabolic surgery (BMS).
results_summary: Splenic abscess was the most common complication (44.2%), often caused by leaks, with fever and abdominal pain as primary symptoms. CT scans were the most used diagnostic tool, and prompt treatment was emphasized to prevent life-threatening outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric/metabolic surgery (BMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the adjuvant benefits of regional anesthetic techniques and other pain management methods in reducing postoperative pain and opioid consumption after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that regional analgesia techniques, particularly transversus abdominis plane and rectus sheath block, significantly reduced postoperative pain scores and opioid consumption. External oblique intercostal block alone showed similar effectiveness in reducing opioid use.
population_specificity: 113 patients who underwent laparoscopic bariatric surgery between January 2019 and December 2021.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare respiratory muscle strength and postoperative pain in patients undergoing gastric bypass via laparotomy versus laparoscopy during hospitalization.
results_summary: Laparotomy patients showed reduced respiratory muscle strength post-surgery without returning to baseline by discharge, along with more severe pain and longer operative times, while laparoscopy patients showed no significant changes in respiratory pressure measurements.
population_specificity: 60 patients with BMI ≥40 kg/m², excluding smokers, those with prior lung diseases, or inability to perform the exam correctly.
study_duration: Immediate postoperative, first, and second postoperative days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal vitamin D supplementation strategy for improving serum 25(OH) vitamin D levels in patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation modestly improved vitamin D status in bariatric surgery patients, particularly at dosages above 2850 IU/day and in patients with BMI greater than 50 kg/m². The standardized mean difference was 0.53 (95% CI: 0.28, 0.77).
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery, particularly those with BMI > 50 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of reloxaliase in reducing urinary oxalate excretion in patients with enteric hyperoxaluria, including a subgroup analysis of bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: Reloxaliase significantly reduced 24-hour urinary oxalate excretion by 22.6% compared to 9.7% for placebo, with a more pronounced effect (21.2% reduction) in the bariatric surgery subgroup. Adverse events were common but mostly mild and did not lead to discontinuation.
population_specificity: Patients with enteric hyperoxaluria, including a subgroup who had undergone bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Three to five times per day with food.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the underlying kinetic changes responsible for hypoglycinemia in obesity and whether bariatric surgery affects glycine metabolism.
results_summary: Participants with morbid obesity had significantly lower plasma glycine concentrations and impaired glycine kinetics compared to controls, suggesting a metabolic alteration linked to obesity.
population_specificity: Participants with morbid obesity (BMI ≥ 32.5 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of probiotic supplementation on binge eating and food addiction in patients after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation significantly reduced food addiction symptoms and binge eating scores one year after surgery compared to placebo, with statistically significant differences (p=0.037 and p=0.030, respectively). Both groups showed improvement at 90 days post-surgery, but the probiotic group had better long-term outcomes.
population_specificity: 101 patients who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.
effective_dosage: Lactobacillus acidophilus NCFM and Bifidobacterium lactis Bi-07 (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of FDA-regulated weight loss devices in increasing the adoption of bariatric surgery for severe obesity in children and adolescents.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the underutilization of bariatric surgery in pediatric populations and highlights four categories of weight loss devices approved for adults, suggesting their potential applicability for children and adolescents. No specific outcomes or efficacy data are provided.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide practical recommendations for the perioperative management of diabetes in patients with type 2 or type 1 diabetes undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery improves glycemic control and can induce diabetes remission in type 2 diabetes, while in type 1 diabetes, it enhances insulin sensitivity and reduces cardiometabolic risk factors. Perioperative glycemic management should focus on avoiding hyperglycemia, primarily using insulin, with close post-surgical follow-up for medication adjustments.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity and obesity-related diseases, specifically those with type 2 or type 1 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a single peri-operative intravenous antibiotic (cefazolin or clindamycin) could alter the gut microbiome composition after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and influence metabolic outcomes.
results_summary: RYGB induced significant gut microbiome changes at 2 weeks, persisting at 3 months post-surgery. The peri-operative antibiotic caused unique, antibiotic-specific microbiome alterations, with clindamycin increasing Bifidobacterium spp., potentially enhancing metabolic efficacy for blood pressure resolution.
population_specificity: 16 patients (87.5% female, average age 48.6 ± 12.2 years, pre-operative BMI 50.9 ± 23.3 kg/m²) undergoing RYGB.
effective_dosage: Single peri-operative dose of intravenous cefazolin or clindamycin.
study_duration: Follow-up at 2 weeks and 3 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic impact and molecular changes in subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) following different types of bariatric surgery, focusing on weight loss and comorbidity remission.
results_summary: Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD-DS) resulted in significantly greater weight loss and higher rates of type 2 diabetes and dyslipidemia remission compared to gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy. Molecular analysis revealed extensive remodeling of SAT, particularly after BPD-DS, with reduced immune and inflammatory responses.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery in reducing hypertension and obesity-related outcomes in patients with non-morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study found only three systematic reviews with critically low methodological quality, reporting results favoring metabolic surgery but with very low certainty of evidence. Outcomes included pressure reduction, hypertension rate, and changes in systolic and diastolic pressure.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertension and non-morbid obesity.
study_duration: Follow-up periods included 1 year and more than 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review sustainable, practical, and scalable approaches to reversing type 2 diabetes (T2DM), including bariatric surgery, and highlight the evidence base for practitioners.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that T2DM reversal is achievable through various therapeutic approaches, including bariatric surgery, but notes that it is not yet standardized in practice and long-term outcomes remain uncertain.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on T2DM reversal approaches)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms behind bariatric surgery's metabolic benefits, particularly focusing on gut-brain communication and its role in weight regulation and co-morbidity resolution.
results_summary: The study highlights bariatric surgery as an effective treatment for obesity and type 2 diabetes, with proposed mechanisms involving gut-brain signaling, though these mechanisms are not yet fully understood.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity and type 2 diabetes population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comparatively evaluate the efficacy of metabolic surgery against restrictive procedures and standard first-line treatment for patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Metabolic surgery was statistically superior to restrictive procedures, medical therapy, and lifestyle intervention in achieving T2DM remission, and it significantly lowered BMI and blood pressure compared to other interventions. Restrictive procedures increased high-density lipoprotein, while lifestyle intervention and metabolic surgery were superior in reducing low-density lipoprotein.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of machine learning applications in bariatric surgery, focusing on predicting postoperative complications and weight loss.
results_summary: Machine learning algorithms demonstrated high accuracy (up to 98%) in predicting postoperative complications and weight loss outcomes in bariatric surgery, though clinical introduction depends on external validation.
population_specificity: Not specified (studies reviewed likely included bariatric surgery patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of exercise and controlled trial methods in adults awaiting or having undergone bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that exercise interventions and controlled trial methods appear feasible and acceptable, with high attendance (84%) and retention (87%) rates, though reporting limitations may affect accuracy. Pooled enrollment and refusal rates were 43% and 23%, respectively.
population_specificity: Adults awaiting or having undergone bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the association between obesity and colorectal cancer (CRC), including the potential role of bariatric surgery as a prophylactic measure.
results_summary: The study found that obesity is associated with a 30%-70% increased risk of colon cancer in men, with less consistent results in women. It suggested that bariatric surgery might be considered as a prophylactic measure for certain obese patients, though many questions remain unanswered.
population_specificity: Obese individuals, including those with childhood or maternal obesity, and their association with CRC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine warfarin dosing recommendations and assess thrombotic and bleeding risks in patients requiring long-term warfarin therapy after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found a decrease in average warfarin dose post-surgery, with the largest reduction at 1 month, followed by a return toward baseline by 90 days. No thrombotic events were observed, but bleeding risk increased, particularly in RYGB patients.
population_specificity: Patients requiring long-term warfarin therapy after bariatric surgery for obesity (160 patients across six studies).
effective_dosage: Weekly warfarin dose (sum of daily doses for 7 days), with a suggested 25% reduction immediately post-surgery.
study_duration: Follow-up included data up to 90 days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanisms contributing to impaired bone health in youth following sleeve gastrectomy (SG).
results_summary: SG led to greater reductions in BMI z-scores, serum estrone, and free androgen index, along with increased sclerostin and bone turnover markers compared to nonsurgical controls. Bone loss after SG was associated with changes in body composition, sex steroids, sclerostin, and enteric peptides.
population_specificity: Youth aged 13-25 years with moderate-to-severe obesity (51 females, 13 males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the medico-economic outcomes of a day-case bariatric surgery pathway versus the conventional inpatient pathway, focusing on cost, safety, and patient satisfaction.
results_summary: Day-case bariatric surgery showed a 14.4% cost reduction, similar complication rates (6.6% in both groups), and significantly shorter hospital stays (0.65 vs. 2.9 days) compared to inpatient surgery. Patient satisfaction and safety profiles were comparable between the two pathways.
population_specificity: 30 patients eligible for bariatric surgery (male-to-female ratio 1/2) with similar age, BMI, and medical conditions in both day-case and inpatient groups.
study_duration: From preoperative visit to 30-day postoperative visit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of exercise on muscle strength in adults following bariatric surgery, specifically focusing on preventing and treating sarcopenic obesity.
results_summary: Exercise interventions improved upper and lower limb muscle strength, as measured by repetition maximum tests, sit-to-stand, and dynamometer tests, but not handgrip strength. The certainty level of the meta-analyses was very low.
population_specificity: Adults who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to address the lack of a standard definition for clinically significant weight recurrence after bariatric surgery and introduce new terminology for weight-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery is the most reliable treatment for obesity but notes some patients experience weight recurrence. It reviews existing definitions for weight recurrence and proposes new terms to better describe post-surgical outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (ESG) as an alternative to bariatric surgery, particularly for patients who refuse or are unfit for surgical options.
results_summary: The study found that ESG shows promising efficacy and safety, with evidence supporting results up to 24 months and some studies reporting 5-year data. When combined with pharmacotherapy, ESG may achieve weight loss comparable to surgical sleeve gastrectomy.
population_specificity: Patients who are refusing or unfit for bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Up to 5 years (based on some studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) on volumetric bone mineral density (vBMD), bone quality, and the agreement between DXA and QCT/HR-pQCT estimates of bone loss.
results_summary: RYGB was associated with significant reductions in vBMD at all skeletal sites analyzed, with time post-surgery significantly linked to deterioration. DXA underestimated lumbar spine and overestimated total hip bone losses compared to QCT/HR-pQCT.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing RYGB with ≥6 months follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the incidence, cause, treatment, and outcome of rare complications (chyloperitoneum and chylothorax) following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that chyloperitoneum and chylothorax are rare complications after bariatric surgery, with 40 reported cases (38 chyloperitoneum, 2 chylothorax). Most patients were treated laparoscopically, and one underwent thoracoscopy with thoracic duct ligation.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery and experienced chyloperitoneum or chylothorax.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate molecular and inter-organ signaling pathways responsible for bariatric surgery-induced weight loss and metabolic benefits, focusing on Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and vertical sleeve gastrectomy (VSG).
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery's effects likely involve multiple signaling pathways rather than a single mechanism, with gut-brain communication playing a major role. No clear, unique mechanism has been identified, but the benefits are sustained over decades in most patients.
population_specificity: Humans and rodents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current applications of artificial intelligence in bariatric surgery, focusing on its role in clinical pathways from risk assessment to outcome prediction.
results_summary: The study found that machine learning algorithms showed remarkable results in aiding decision-making, improving care quality, and advancing precision medicine in bariatric surgery. However, legal and ethical hurdles remain before widespread clinical adoption.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review of 36 articles)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of (morbid) obesity on ciprofloxacin pharmacokinetics after oral and intravenous administration to guide dosing in this population.
results_summary: The study found no significant influence of body weight on ciprofloxacin pharmacokinetic parameters, suggesting no need for routine dosage increases in obese individuals. However, lower soft tissue concentrations were predicted in obese individuals, indicating potential need for higher dosages in tissue infections with impaired penetration.
population_specificity: (Morbidly) obese individuals undergoing bariatric surgery and non-obese participants.
effective_dosage: Oral (500 mg; n = 10), intravenous (400 mg; n = 10), and semi-simultaneous oral (500 mg) followed by intravenous (400 mg) in non-obese participants (n = 8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of weight loss programs, including bariatric surgery, in reducing back pain and disability or improving quality of life for individuals with low back pain.
results_summary: Very low-quality evidence from single-arm studies suggests that back pain improved from baseline after bariatric surgery, but most studies were of poor quality due to selection bias, uncontrolled confounders, and lack of blinding.
population_specificity: Individuals with low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and describe latent classes of weight loss, physical activity, and eating style changes up to 5 years after bariatric surgery and examine their interrelations.
results_summary: The study identified five distinct weight loss trajectories, with most patients showing stable or partial-regain patterns. Patients with the most favorable weight loss trajectory were more likely to follow favorable eating style trajectories, while those with unfavorable weight loss trajectories did not show significant increases in physical activity.
population_specificity: 2785 patients undergoing bariatric surgery in a multicenter outpatient clinic setting.

study_goal: To evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in managing NAFLD/NASH in individuals with obesity.
results_summary: The study suggests bariatric surgery as a management option for NAFLD/NASH in individuals with obesity, alongside lifestyle changes and other medications, but does not provide specific efficacy data.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and NAFLD/NASH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of weight loss via bariatric surgery on glucocorticoid metabolism and intracranial pressure in patients with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH).
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery reduced systemic 11β-HSD1 and 5α-reductase activity, which was associated with decreased intracranial pressure in IIH patients. Subcutaneous adipose tissue explants showed elevated 11β-HSD1 activity in IIH patients compared to controls.
population_specificity: Female IIH patients matched with BMI, age, and sex-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which revisional bariatric procedure performs best after the failure of primary restrictive surgery, focusing on weight loss, morbidity, and weight regain.
results_summary: Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch showed the best weight loss results, while single-anastomosis duodenoileal bypass and one-anastomosis gastric bypass were the most effective revisional procedures overall due to satisfying weight loss and low morbidity. Re-sleeve gastrectomy had the highest risk of weight regain.
population_specificity: Patients who experienced failure of primary restrictive bariatric surgery (e.g., insufficient weight loss, weight regain, or complications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of drug therapy versus bariatric surgery for achieving complete remission of PCOS in women with obesity.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery resulted in a significantly higher complete remission rate (78%) compared to drug therapy (15%), with final BMI being the major factor influencing remission. Nearly 95% of patients with an endpoint BMI below cutoff values achieved complete remission.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-40 with BMI ≥27.5 kg/m², waist circumference ≥85 cm, and diagnosed with PCOS according to 2011 Chinese criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of preoperative dietary protocols on weight loss and surgical complications in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that VLCKD was associated with better weight reduction and lower postoperative complications, while LCD showed better tolerance and adherence than VLCD. However, evidence remains inconclusive, with no clear superiority between VLCD and LCD, and a need for more controlled studies.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review key issues internists should be aware of for supporting patients' health in the short and long term after metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS).
results_summary: The study found that MBS is effective for weight loss, associated with reduced mortality, and improves obesity-related health conditions and quality of life. However, it also noted postsurgical anatomical and physiological changes requiring ongoing monitoring of physical and mental health.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the association between gut microbes and bariatric surgery and evaluate the beneficial role of gut microbes in improving therapeutic outcomes of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery alters gut microbiota and enhances the synthesis of short-chain fatty acids, contributing to better clinical outcomes, weight loss, and reduced adverse events post-surgery. Prebiotics, probiotics, and postbiotics are recommended to improve these outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery for obesity management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) versus sleeve gastrectomy (SG) on lipid metabolism in type 2 diabetes (T2DM) patients 12 months after surgery.
results_summary: RYGB was more effective than SG in reducing total cholesterol, LDL-C, and non-HDL-C levels, with statistically significant improvements. Despite greater weight loss and glycemic control improvements with RYGB, both procedures showed benefits in lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: T2DM patients with obesity (298 patients total: 151 RYGB, 147 SG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether intraperitoneal instillation of local anesthetic (IPILA) reduces opioid requirements and pain in patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that IPILA significantly reduced post-operative pain in the recovery room but did not reduce opioid use, antiemetic use, or length of stay. There were no significant differences in morbidity or mortality between the intervention and placebo groups.
population_specificity: 104 patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery (54 placebo, 50 IPILA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether bariatric surgery improves left ventricular systolic function in patients with morbid obesity and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.
results_summary: The study found that significant weight loss following bariatric surgery was associated with improvements in left ventricular systolic function. The analysis was retrospective and focused on patients treated between 2010 and 2019.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity (BMI >35 kg/m²) and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of apixaban for thromboprophylaxis following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that 30 days of postoperative apixaban was safe and effective, with minimal side effects (1.7%) and very low thromboembolic complication rates (0.1%). No deaths or thromboembolic events occurred when the protocol was fully followed.
population_specificity: 5017 consecutive bariatric surgery patients from three private institutes in the USA.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the association between metformin use, vitamin B12 deficiency, and neuropathy, with bariatric surgery noted as a factor accelerating vitamin B12 depletion.
results_summary: The abstract does not present specific findings about bariatric surgery's effects but mentions it as a factor that accelerates the loss of hepatic vitamin B12 stores, potentially exacerbating neuropathy in metformin users.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes utilizing metformin, particularly those with prolonged use (over 5 years), elderly individuals, and those with increased red blood cell turnover.
interactions: Proton pump inhibitors, bariatric surgery, and increased red blood cell turnover are noted as factors accelerating vitamin B12 depletion.

study_goal: The researchers explored a novel therapeutic approach to engineer autologous T cells into acquiring a thermogenic phenotype like brown fat as a potential treatment for obesity, rather than focusing on bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the limitations of conventional obesity treatments, including bariatric surgery, and proposes engineered thermogenic T cells as a novel strategy to increase resting energy expenditure without the risks of pharmacological mitochondrial uncoupling.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical approach, not yet applied to a specific population)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and variability of bariatric surgery as a treatment for hypothalamic obesity.
results_summary: The study found that the impact of bariatric surgery on weight loss in hypothalamic obesity is variable, with some reports of weight loss or stabilization but inconsistent results overall. Novel or combined approaches are suggested for more credible and sustained outcomes.
population_specificity: Children and young people with hypothalamic obesity, particularly those affected by craniopharyngioma or related interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) in metabolic diseases and their implications for pre- and post-operative metabolic profiling in bariatric surgery candidates.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that high BCAA levels are linked to metabolic diseases like insulin resistance and obesity, while low BCAA diets may promote metabolic health. It also mentions that BCAA accumulation may alter lipid metabolism, though this is not widely accepted.
population_specificity: Candidate patients for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of perioperative psychological interventions on weight loss, BMI, quality of life, and psychosocial health in patients with clinically severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Perioperative psychological interventions showed little to no benefit for BMI and uncertain effects on weight-related and psychosocial outcomes, with evidence considered anecdotal and ambiguous. The study suggests more high-quality research is needed to determine the true effect.
population_specificity: Patients with clinically severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery (1060 participants: 365 males, 693 females, 2 with missing data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in improving metabolic parameters and renal function in obese patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study suggests that bariatric surgery, along with other therapies, may improve glomerular hyperfiltration and metabolic parameters, potentially aiding nephroprotection in CKD patients. However, the abstract does not provide specific data on the extent of these improvements.
population_specificity: Obese patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the connection between obesity, atrial fibrillation (AF), and epicardial adipose tissue (EAT), and to review the effects of bariatric and metabolic surgery on EAT and AF.
results_summary: The study suggests that EAT plays a pivotal role in the relationship between obesity and AF, and bariatric surgery may impact EAT and AF, though the superior treatment strategy remains uncertain due to complex pathophysiology.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and associated atrial fibrillation (AF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of physical activity on weight loss and biomarkers in adults undergoing bariatric surgery and identify successful interventions for this population.
results_summary: The study found that physical activity significantly impacted BMI reduction (SMD = -0.93) but showed no significant differences for other outcomes like fat-free mass, fat mass, waist-hip ratio, or waist circumference. High heterogeneity among trials was noted.
population_specificity: Adults who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze different surgical techniques for treating obesity and determine the most effective approaches based on patient characteristics and surgical team experience.
results_summary: The study found that restrictive techniques, particularly vertical gastrectomy, and mixed techniques like gastric bypass (considered the "gold standard") are the most commonly used for bariatric surgery. The choice of technique depends on individual patient factors and the surgical team's expertise.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity requiring surgical intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a multicomponent exercise intervention after bariatric surgery improves balance in patients with obesity.
results_summary: The study found that the exercise intervention improved certain balance parameters (e.g., CoG displacement and velocity) in patients post-bariatric surgery, while no significant differences were observed in anthropometric, muscle strength, or vitamin D variables between the exercise and control groups.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity who underwent bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Supervised multicomponent training program (3 days/week; 75 min/session).

study_goal: To determine whether bariatric surgery before total knee arthroplasty (TKA) improves outcomes and reduces complications in people with BMI ≥ 35 and end-stage osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery reduced TKA complications (14.6% vs. 36.6% in the control group) and led to significant weight loss (BMI difference of -6.32 at 12 months). Fewer participants in the surgery group required TKA due to symptom improvement (29.3% vs. 4.9%).
population_specificity: Adults with BMI ≥ 35 and end-stage osteoarthritis scheduled for TKA (mean age 57.8 years, 80.5% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the usability and effectiveness of a structured postoperative care program (BagEL) for bariatric surgery patients in primary care settings.
results_summary: General practitioners rated the new aftercare booklet (BMP) significantly more helpful for treating bariatric patients compared to the control group's information sheet (p = 0.041), indicating improved support for long-term follow-up care.
population_specificity: 124 patients who underwent first-time bariatric surgery and their general practitioners.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review bariatric surgery outcomes in patients with hyperphagic disorders, including Prader-Willi syndrome, MC4R mutations, Bardet-Biedl syndrome, and hypothalamic obesity.
results_summary: Weight loss in Prader-Willi syndrome patients was greatest within the first year post-surgery but not significantly different from baseline at 5 years. Long-term outcomes in other conditions were inconsistent, with suboptimal weight loss and higher reoperation risks.
population_specificity: Patients with Prader-Willi syndrome (114), MC4R mutations (43), Bardet-Biedl syndrome (7), and hypothalamic obesity (38).
study_duration: Follow-up periods varied, up to 14 years for Prader-Willi syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implications of bariatric surgery on antiretroviral pharmacokinetics and outcomes in people living with HIV, and to provide recommendations for antiretroviral treatment in this population.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery can significantly alter antiretroviral pharmacokinetics, potentially leading to subtherapeutic exposure and treatment failure. It highlighted the need for pharmacokinetic studies to guide antiretroviral choice post-surgery.
population_specificity: People living with HIV undergoing bariatric surgery.
interactions: Interactions noted with polyvalent cations in supplements and drugs inhibiting gastric acid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between serum transferrin levels and the severity of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in bariatric surgery candidates, while accounting for obesity-related confounders.
results_summary: The study found that serum transferrin levels were significantly higher in patients with moderate/severe OSA compared to those with no/mild OSA, independent of obesity. Higher transferrin levels were associated with greater hypoxia severity, suggesting a potential biomarker role for OSA severity.
population_specificity: 270 bariatric surgery candidates, with propensity score-matched analysis reducing the sample to 75 patients per group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effects and complications of medical treatment (MT) with bariatric surgery (RYGB and SG) in individuals with obesity.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery (RYGB and SG) resulted in significantly greater weight loss (82.5% and 70.3% decrease in excess BMI, respectively) compared to MT (27.5%). Surgical groups also had higher treatment success rates, with comparable safety measures and positive effects on well-being and metabolic variables.
population_specificity: Individuals with BMI ≥35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of bariatric surgery on obesity, comorbidities, and metabolic alterations, particularly focusing on changes in the microbiome and circulating metabolites.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery effectively treats obesity and reduces comorbidities but causes metabolic alterations and significant changes in the microbiome and circulating metabolites, which may influence metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery on nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in patients with obesity, focusing on biopsy-confirmed remission and liver function improvements.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly improved NAFLD, with resolution rates of 56% for steatosis, 49% for ballooning degeneration, 45% for inflammation, and 25% for fibrosis. RYGB and SG showed notable benefits, with Asian patients experiencing higher improvements in steatosis and fibrosis.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare two methods of laparoscopic one anastomosis gastric bypass (LOAGB)—experimental (with wrapping) versus standard (non-wrapping)—to assess their effectiveness in preventing weight regain and biliary reflux.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a randomized controlled trial to evaluate outcomes (BMI, bile reflux, reflux symptoms) over 36 months, but results are not yet reported as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: 100 obese patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term weight loss results and comorbidity effects of banded versus non-banded Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).
results_summary: Banded RYGB showed superior weight loss compared to non-banded RYGB, but no difference in comorbidity improvement or remission was observed. Complication rates were similar between the two methods.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent primary RYGB between July 2013 and December 2014 and completed a 5-year follow-up program in the Dutch Obesity Clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dietary experience of patients with obesity following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Most patients could control their diet shortly after surgery, but long-term dietary management required gradual self-awareness and postoperative support. The study synthesized findings from 24 qualitative studies involving 383 participants.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review currently available and upcoming endoscopic bariatric and metabolic therapies (EBMTs), including their safety, efficacy, and procedural details.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results on bariatric surgery but indicates a focus on summarizing EBMTs, their mechanisms, and pivotal study data.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity population implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of metabolic surgery on obese patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: Metabolic surgery significantly improved abnormal menstruation, hirsutism, and hormone levels (testosterone, SHBG, AMH) in PCOS patients, with postoperative pregnancy rates ranging from 95.2% to 100% in small sample studies.
population_specificity: Obese patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review therapeutic options for patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) relapse following metabolic-bariatric surgery (MBS) and evaluate the suitability of GLP-1 analogues for glycemic and weight control.
results_summary: The study found that GLP-1 analogues are the most suitable option for managing hyperglycemia post-MBS, offering benefits in glycemic control, weight management, and cardiovascular/renal protection. However, long-term data on weekly GLP-1 agents and the impact of MBS on other medications like lipid-lowering and anti-hypertensive drugs remain inconclusive.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes who underwent metabolic-bariatric surgery and experienced relapse.
interactions: Changes in oral drug bioavailability post-MBS were noted, but specific interactions were not detailed.

study_goal: To compare the effects of intravenous lidocaine infusion and ultrasound-guided TAP block on postoperative recovery and analgesia in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: Both lidocaine infusion and TAP block improved postoperative recovery (QoR-40 scores) compared to the control group, with lidocaine providing superior analgesia at 12 and 24 hours post-surgery.
population_specificity: ASA II-III patients undergoing elective laparoscopic bariatric surgery (n=99).
effective_dosage: Lidocaine group: 1.5 mg/kg loading dose at induction, followed by 2 mg/kg/h infusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the diagnostic value of the TyG index, an insulin-resistance indicator, to predict NASH in severely obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The TyG index was independently associated with NASH, NAFLD, and fibrosis, showing high diagnostic performance when combined with GGT levels to predict NASH. The study found steatosis in 67.2% of subjects, NASH in 18.1%, and advanced fibrosis in 2.9%.
population_specificity: Grade II-III obese patients aged 18-65 years undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term antidiabetic effects and efficacy loss over time of key bariatric procedures in type 2 diabetes management.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric procedures like Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, sleeve gastrectomy, and biliopancreatic diversion showed superior diabetes remission rates compared to medical treatment and gastric banding, but efficacy progressively declined over time. The temporal dynamics of efficacy loss were statistically comparable across all procedures.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes undergoing bariatric surgery (1,906 patients across 31 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different exercise types, duration, and onset after bariatric surgery on cardiometabolic risk factors.
results_summary: Exercise, particularly combined aerobic and resistance protocols, effectively reduced systolic blood pressure and triglycerides post-bariatric surgery. Benefits were also observed with interventions starting >6 months post-surgery and lasting >12 weeks.
population_specificity: 618 participants who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of bariatric surgery as a treatment modality for idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), particularly in non-sight-threatening cases.
results_summary: The abstract suggests bariatric surgery is appealing for patients with non-sight-threatening IIH but notes insufficient evidence to support it over other surgical procedures. Further exploration is needed to evaluate its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Obese women of childbearing age with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of large weight loss (≥10%) on obesity-related complications, comparing bariatric surgery and lifestyle interventions.
results_summary: Large weight loss from bariatric surgery or lifestyle modifications improved comorbidities like type 2 diabetes and hypertension, reduced cancer risk, and enhanced quality of life. Bariatric surgery was noted as the most cost-effective intervention despite its high cost.
population_specificity: Patients with overweight or obesity, particularly those with severe obesity or insufficient response to modest weight loss.
effective_dosage: Not specified for bariatric surgery (lifestyle/pharmacotherapy dosages mentioned: phentermine/topiramate 15/92 mg once daily, semaglutide 2.4 mg once weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of bariatric surgery on food tolerance, nutritional status, and health-related quality of life (HRQOL) among patients with morbid obesity in Malaysia.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly reduced weight (31.6% excess weight loss at three months) and improved HRQOL across physical, psychological, social, and environmental domains, despite reduced food tolerance and energy intake post-surgery.
population_specificity: 90 patients with morbid obesity in Malaysia (68.9% female, 50% under 40 years old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery affects blood levels of essential fatty acids (EFAs) and other polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs).
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery leads to a transient decline in blood levels of EFAs and eicosapentaenoic acid, with levels returning to pre-surgery baselines after about 6 months. The results were mixed, with some studies reporting increases and others decreases in specific PUFAs.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing bariatric surgery for severe and complex obesity.
study_duration: Follow-up varied, with transient effects observed up to 6 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the impact of heart failure on exercise tolerance, focusing on abnormalities like reduced maximal oxygen uptake.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings related to Beetroot's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on heart failure patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of beetroot inorganic nitrate supplementation on cardiovascular risk factors in adults, focusing on endothelial function, arterial stiffness, and blood pressure.
results_summary: Beetroot inorganic nitrate supplementation significantly improved arterial stiffness (reduced pulse wave velocity) and endothelial function (increased flow-mediated dilation) but did not affect other cardiovascular parameters. The meta-analysis included 27 randomized clinical trials, supporting these findings.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical utility of phytochemicals, including beetroot, in improving functional outcomes for patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The abstract discusses the potential of phytochemicals to target oxidative stress, skeletal muscle pathology, and nitric oxide bioavailability in PAD, but specific results for beetroot are not detailed. Clinical trials assessing phytochemical effects on PAD functional outcomes are highlighted, though beetroot-specific findings are not explicitly mentioned.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if dietary nitrate from beetroot juice could reduce carotid subclinical atherosclerosis and stiffness compared to placebo over 6 months.
results_summary: Nitrate-containing beetroot juice significantly reduced carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) by ~8% relative to baseline but had no effect on carotid diameter or stiffness. No BP-independent effects on carotid structure or function were observed with spironolactone or doxazosin.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertension and with/at risk of type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of oral inorganic nitrate (from beetroot) on glycemic and lipid parameters in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in glycemic or lipid parameters between the beetroot and placebo groups. Safety measures, including liver and renal function tests, showed no undesirable changes.
population_specificity: Patients with T2DM (mean age 54.0 ± 8.5 years, 47.9% male, mean diabetes duration 8.5 ± 6.1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nitrate-rich beetroot juice (BJ) acutely improves vascular function, measured by flow-mediated dilation (FMD) and pulse wave velocity (PWV), in healthy individuals and HIV-infected patients.
results_summary: BJ ingestion acutely improved %FMD in both healthy and HIV-infected groups compared to placebo, with no significant changes in PWV. No improvements were observed after placebo ingestion in either group.
population_specificity: 13 HIV-infected individuals (age 36 ± 10 years) and 18 healthy controls (age 27 ± 8 years).
study_duration: Acute effects measured at 120 minutes post-ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of 12 weeks of increased daily consumption of nitrate-rich vegetables or beetroot juice supplementation on blood pressure in (pre)hypertensive middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: The study found that a prolonged dietary intervention with nitrate-rich vegetables significantly lowered systolic blood pressure, while beetroot juice supplementation showed no significant change. The control group experienced an increase in systolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: (Pre)hypertensive middle-aged and older adults (average age 65 ± 10 years, blood pressure 144 ± 13/87 ± 7 mmHg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether co-administration of vitamin C and nitrate (via beetroot juice) for 4 weeks would improve endothelial function, plasma NO metabolites, oxidative stress, and blood lipids in subjects with hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: No significant differences in endothelial function (RHI) were observed between treatments, but a subgroup with baseline endothelial dysfunction showed improvement with the combined intervention. The combined treatment significantly increased plasma NO metabolites and reduced LDL and triglycerides, while also lowering oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Adults aged 50-70 with LDL > 130 mg/dL and RHI ≤2 (indicating endothelial dysfunction).
effective_dosage: 70 ml concentrated beetroot juice (CBJ) with 1000 mg vitamin C or CBJ with placebo, daily.
study_duration: 4 weeks per treatment, with a 2-week washout between treatments.

study_goal: The researchers were exploring alternative physiological pathways, such as nitric oxide generation, for treating hypertension in pregnancy due to limitations in current chemotherapeutic regimes.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Beetroot's effects, focusing instead on the broader context of hypertension treatment in pregnancy.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals with chronic hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of beetroot supplementation in reducing exercise-induced muscle damage (EIMD).
results_summary: Beetroot supplementation was found to have a prophylactic effect in reducing EIMD, indicating potential benefits for recovery. The evidence places it among interventions with a good level of support, though inconsistencies in dosing and frequency were noted.
population_specificity: Athletes or individuals experiencing exercise-induced muscle damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on dietary patterns and nutraceuticals, including beetroot juice, associated with lower blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found that beetroot juice, among other nutraceuticals, can lower blood pressure, likely due to its antihypertensive properties. The effects are mediated by factors like improved inflammation and insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: Normotensive, prehypertensive, and hypertensive populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if nitrate supplementation via beetroot juice could improve cardiac measures during submaximal exercise in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
results_summary: The study found that beetroot juice supplementation increased plasma nitrate levels significantly (~1028%), but specific outcomes on cardiac output, stroke volume, or total peripheral resistance were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Five male participants (61 ± 3 years) with HFrEF (EF 32 ± 2.2%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (NR-BJ) improves muscle oxygen saturation parameters during and after exercise in HIV-infected patients undergoing HAART.
results_summary: NR-BJ significantly improved muscle oxygen desaturation and resaturation rates during exercise and recovery compared to nitrate-depleted beetroot juice (ND-BJ), but no difference in exercise time until fatigue was observed. Salivary nitrite and urinary nitrate levels were also significantly higher after NR-BJ consumption.
population_specificity: HIV-infected patients undergoing HAART with expected microvascular damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of nitrate-rich vegetables and beetroot juice supplementation on plasma nitrate/nitrite concentrations and blood pressure.
results_summary: Both interventions increased plasma nitrate and nitrite concentrations, with beetroot juice showing a larger increase. Both significantly reduced post-lunch systolic and diastolic blood pressure to similar extents.
population_specificity: Healthy men and women (n=30, age 24±6 years) from the Netherlands.
effective_dosage: ~400 mg nitrate at lunch, provided through nitrate-rich vegetables or beetroot juice.
study_duration: 1 week per intervention, with a 1-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grapefruit juice enhances the blood pressure-lowering effects of beetroot juice by inhibiting nitrite re-oxidation.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice enhanced beetroot juice's effect on lowering systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure, despite decreasing plasma nitrite levels, suggesting complex mechanisms beyond nitrite maintenance.
population_specificity: 11 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 70 mL active beetroot juice (Beet-It) and 250 mL grapefruit juice or water
interactions: Grapefruit juice (CYP3A4 inhibitor) interacted with beetroot juice's nitrate-nitrite-nitric oxide pathway.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether dietary nitrate supplementation via beetroot juice could enhance the effects of pulmonary rehabilitation in individuals with COPD.
results_summary: The study found that nitrate-rich beetroot juice significantly improved exercise capacity (incremental shuttle walk test distance) and reduced systolic blood pressure compared to placebo, with no significant serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Adults with moderate to severe COPD (Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease grade II-IV) and significant dyspnea or functional limitation.
effective_dosage: 140 mL of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (12.9 mmol nitrate), consumed 3 hours prior to each pulmonary rehabilitation session, twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if oral inorganic nitrate supplementation (from beetroot) could improve exercise capacity, vascular function, and mitochondrial respiration in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
results_summary: The study suggests that inorganic nitrate supplementation increases nitric oxide bioavailability, potentially improving exercise capacity, vascular function, and mitochondrial respiration in HFrEF patients. However, specific quantitative results or statistical significance are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Sixteen patients with HFrEF (15 men, average age 63 ± 4 years, BMI 31.8 ± 2.1 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antihypertensive effects of dietary components and natural products, including beetroot juice, in patients with high-normal blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found that beetroot juice has the most convincing evidence of antihypertensive effects among the foods evaluated. It suggests that beetroot juice could be considered for patients with high-normal blood pressure.
population_specificity: Patients with high-normal blood pressure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic potential of red beetroot and its active compounds (betalains) for various health benefits, including antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, and disease-modifying effects.
results_summary: The study found that red beetroot and its active compounds, particularly betanin, exhibit multiple health benefits such as antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, anticancer, blood pressure and lipid-lowering effects, as well as antidiabetic and anti-obesity properties. The review highlights beetroot's potential as a supplemental therapy for various diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of beetroot juice to improve physical activity participation and counter cancer-related fatigue in children with cancer.
results_summary: The review found a lack of clinical trials on beetroot use in cancer populations, with existing trials conducted only in noncancer populations. No conclusive evidence was presented regarding beetroot's efficacy for the intended outcomes.
population_specificity: Children with cancer (though trials reviewed were in noncancer populations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if dietary nitrate from beetroot juice could reduce arterial stiffness (measured as aortic pulse wave velocity) independently of blood pressure in at-risk or type-2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: Beetroot juice increased circulating nitrate and nitrite levels and selectively lowered central systolic pressure but did not reduce arterial stiffness measures (CAVI or PWVart). No significant effect on peripheral pressure was observed.
population_specificity: People at risk or with type-2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily dietary inorganic nitrate (from beetroot juice) reduces left ventricular mass and improves arterial stiffness in hypertensive patients with suboptimal blood pressure control.
results_summary: The study was designed to detect significant changes in left ventricular mass, pulse wave velocity, and central blood pressure, with high statistical power (>90-95%) for these outcomes, suggesting potential efficacy, though specific results are not yet reported in the abstract. Secondary endpoints included changes in flow-mediated dilation, plasma nitrate/nitrite levels, and blood pressure.
population_specificity: 160 hypertensive patients with suboptimal blood pressure control on one or more antihypertensives.
effective_dosage: Once daily dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (exact amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary nitrate supplementation via beetroot could improve nitric oxide availability and microvascular blood flow in lowlanders exposed to hypobaric hypoxia at high altitude.
results_summary: Dietary nitrate supplementation significantly increased plasma nitrate, nitrite, and total nitroso product levels but had no effect on sublingual or forearm blood flow, even under supplemental oxygen conditions. The study concluded that beetroot supplementation did not improve microcirculatory function at high altitude.
population_specificity: 28 healthy adult lowlanders residing at 4559 m for 1 week.
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-nitrate beetroot supplement vs. low-nitrate placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if integrating beetroot into a snack bar could increase children's liking for vegetables and how exposure frequency influenced intake and liking.
results_summary: The study found that repeated exposure increased liking for the beetroot/carrot bar, but this did not generalize to overall vegetable liking. The boredom group, exposed daily, showed lower intake and no significant liking increase.
population_specificity: 256 children aged 7-10 years from 12 school classes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (bars were provided every second day for most groups, daily for the boredom group).
study_duration: 8 exposures (duration not explicitly stated, but likely ~2 weeks based on frequency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether consuming a high-nitrate leafy green salad (similar to beetroot in nitrate content) twice daily for 10 days improved plasma nitrate/nitrite concentration and cardiovascular health measures in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that plasma nitrate/nitrite concentration and flow-mediated dilation would improve after the leafy green salad treatment, but the abstract does not provide specific results.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (52.6 ± 4.9 years; BMI 26.4 ± 6.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: High-nitrate leafy green salad twice daily (exact nitrate content not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of inorganic nitrate, including from beetroot, on blood pressure in hypertensive adults.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with some showing no change in blood pressure, others showing decreases in systolic and/or diastolic pressure, but concluded insufficient evidence to support or refute inorganic nitrate's effects.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ with blood pressure >120/80 mmHg, some with comorbidities like diabetes or heart failure.
effective_dosage: Varied (beetroot juice, gel, high nitrate diet, etc.); specific doses not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether beetroot juice could protect against cold symptoms during periods of psychological stress, particularly in students undergoing final exams.
results_summary: Beetroot juice was associated with reduced cold and sickness symptoms during and after finals, with the greatest benefits observed in participants with asthma. Higher exhaled nitric oxide levels were linked to reduced symptomatology.
population_specificity: 76 students (16 with asthma) undergoing final exams.
effective_dosage: Seven daily doses (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effect of beetroot juice on post-exercise ambulatory blood pressure in obese individuals.
results_summary: Beetroot juice significantly increased plasma nitrite and nitrate concentrations and reduced systolic blood pressure for up to 6 hours post-exercise compared to control and low-nitrate drink conditions, with no significant effect on diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Non-hypertensive obese males with an elevated cardiovascular risk profile.
study_duration: Single session with follow-up measurements up to 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between beetroot consumption and blood platelet activation, focusing on its potential role in cardiovascular disease prophylaxis and treatment.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that beetroot, along with other vegetables, may have beneficial effects on blood platelet hyperactivity, a key cardiovascular risk factor, but the mechanisms remain unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes of nitrate-rich beetroot juice in patients with heart failure.
